news_summary: Today’s positive news highlights heartwarming animal friendships and the impactful advancements in science driven by China’s ambitious talent recruitment.
news_summary_fr: Les nouvelles positives d'aujourd'hui mettent en lumière des amitiés animales réconfortantes et des avancées scientifiques importantes grâce au recrutement ambitieux de talents par la Chine.
news_summary_es: Las noticias positivas de hoy destacan las enternecedoras amistades entre animales y los impactantes avances científicos impulsados por la ambiciosa captación de talentos en China.

articles.title: Puppy and cheetah cub make unlikely pair of step-siblings
articles.summary: An Australian zoo has recruited a puppy to help socialise a precious cheetah cub after she had to be separated from her mother, and the two have become firm friends
articles.content:
An Australian zoo has recruited a puppy to help socialise a precious cheetah cub after she had to be separated from her mother, and the two have become firm friends

The playful pair of Rozi the cheetah cub and Ziggy the labrador-kelpie-collie mix show that sibling bonds can transcend species boundaries.

Rozi was born in late February at Western Plains Zoo in Dubbo, Australia, by emergency caesarean after her mother, Siri, went into labour early.

Advertisement

Siri never produced milk, and because Rozi was critically unwell for the first weeks of her life, the mother and daughter had to be separated.

Rozi’s two siblings were stillborn, so as the sole surviving cub, she faced the prospect of at least 18 months in isolation, leaving her ill-equipped to join the zoo’s breeding programme.

Zookeepers decided that if Rozi was going to develop and socialise normally, giving her the best chance of successfully breeding one day, she would need a step-sibling.

Free newsletter Sign up to The Earth Edition Unmissable news about our planet, delivered straight to your inbox each month. Sign up to newsletter

A decade ago, Rozi’s mother had a dog as a companion, and puppies have also been successfully paired with cheetah cubs in the US, says Jordan Michelmore, a cheetah keeper at the zoo in Dubbo.

A domestic kitten wouldn’t have been suitable, she says, because Rozi’s playmate would need to be tough enough to hold their own with the cheetah for at least a year.

“Dogs have a little bit more resilience and a little bit more energy, and they’ve got that size that more closely matches the cheetah as she grows,” says Michelmore.

Ziggy and Rozi at 3 months old Shallon McReaddie

When both were around 2 months old, Ziggy and Rozi were cautiously introduced to each other. Ziggy, who had to be carefully quarantined and vaccinated, was initially kept on a lead. But after two weeks, the two were playing freely and even sleeping together.

“They match each other so well with their energy level, the type of play that they do and their size,” says Michelmore. “The dopeyness, the lightheartedness and the looseness of a puppy seem to match Rozi pretty well for this stage of life.”

At around 12 to 18 months, female cheetahs become solitary, seeking their own space. That is when keepers expect that Ziggy will need to be separated and adopted out to a new home.

“We’ll just take our cues from them, and when she’s starting to not really want to spend as much time with him, then we can start phasing him out,” Michelmore says.

However, she is also considering adopting Ziggy, which means he and Rozi will have a greater chance of keeping in touch. She says some zoos in the US have found that cheetahs and their adopted siblings can remain close well into adulthood.

She describes Ziggy as being like an “annoying big brother”. “But the joy that we see in her body when he comes back into her yard is just palpable,” she says.

“I’m also hoping Ziggy will also be a very well-rounded dog. He’s got the most unconventional upbringing that a puppy could possibly have.”
articles.reasoning: The story highlights an act of kindness and animal care, showing a puppy helping a cheetah cub socialize after separation from its mother. It reflects compassion, animal welfare, and an unlikely friendship that is heartwarming and positive.
articles.personality_title: Puppy and cheetah cub form heartwarming bond at Australian zoo
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
At Western Plains Zoo in Dubbo, Australia, a cheetah cub named Rozi was born prematurely by emergency cesarean. Sadly, her mother, Siri, could not produce milk, so Rozi had to be separated and cared for differently.

**What happened**
To help Rozi grow and learn social skills, the zoo introduced Ziggy, a playful puppy who mixes labrador, kelpie, and collie breeds. Ziggy’s friendly nature helped Rozi feel safe and loved despite being apart from her mother.

**Impact**
Their growing friendship shows how animals from very different species can form strong bonds. Ziggy’s presence supports Rozi’s emotional and social development, which is crucial for her wellbeing and future.

**What's next step**
The zoo will continue to monitor and care for Rozi, ensuring she thrives with Ziggy’s companionship until she can safely return to a cheetah group. This approach may inspire other zoos to use animal friendships to aid young or vulnerable animals.

**One-sentence takeaway**
A loving puppy helped a lonely cheetah cub grow and thrive, proving friendship knows no species.
articles.personality_title_fr: Un chiot et un bébé guépard forment un lien réconfortant dans un zoo australien
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**
Au zoo de Western Plains à Dubbo, en Australie, un bébé guépard nommé Rozi est né prématurément par césarienne d'urgence. Malheureusement, sa mère Siri n’a pas pu produire de lait, et Rozi a dû être séparée et soignée autrement.

**Ce qui s’est passé**
Pour aider Rozi à grandir et à apprendre à socialiser, le zoo a présenté Ziggy, un chiot joueur mélange de labrador, kelpie et colley. La nature amicale de Ziggy a aidé Rozi à se sentir en sécurité et aimée malgré la séparation de sa mère.

**Impact**
Leur amitié naissante montre que des animaux très différents peuvent créer des liens forts. La présence de Ziggy soutient le développement émotionnel et social de Rozi, essentiel pour son bien-être et son avenir.

**Prochaine étape**
Le zoo continuera de surveiller et de prendre soin de Rozi, en veillant à ce qu’elle s’épanouisse avec la compagnie de Ziggy jusqu’à ce qu’elle puisse rejoindre un groupe de guépards en toute sécurité. Cette approche pourrait inspirer d’autres zoos à utiliser l’amitié animale pour aider les jeunes ou les animaux vulnérables.

**Résumé en une phrase**
Un chiot aimant a aidé un bébé guépard solitaire à grandir et à s’épanouir, prouvant que l’amitié ne connaît pas d’espèce.
articles.personality_title_es: Un cachorro y una cría de guepardo forman un vínculo conmovedor en un zoológico australiano
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**
En el zoológico Western Plains en Dubbo, Australia, nació una cría de guepardo llamada Rozi de forma prematura por cesárea de emergencia. Desafortunadamente, su madre Siri no pudo producir leche, por lo que Rozi tuvo que ser separada y cuidada de forma diferente.

**Qué pasó**
Para ayudar a Rozi a crecer y aprender habilidades sociales, el zoológico presentó a Ziggy, un cachorro juguetón que es mezcla de labrador, kelpie y collie. La naturaleza amigable de Ziggy ayudó a Rozi a sentirse segura y querida a pesar de estar separada de su madre.

**Impacto**
Su creciente amistad muestra cómo animales de especies muy diferentes pueden formar lazos fuertes. La presencia de Ziggy apoya el desarrollo emocional y social de Rozi, algo crucial para su bienestar y futuro.

**Próximo paso**
El zoológico seguirá monitoreando y cuidando a Rozi, asegurándose de que prospere con la compañía de Ziggy hasta que pueda regresar de forma segura a un grupo de guepardos. Este enfoque podría inspirar a otros zoológicos a usar amistades entre animales para ayudar a jóvenes o animales vulnerables.

**Conclusión en una frase**
Un cachorro cariñoso ayudó a una cría de guepardo solitaria a crecer y prosperar, demostrando que la amistad no conoce especies.
articles.image_prompt: A detailed, warm painting of a playful cheetah cub and a lively puppy gently tumbling and nuzzling together in a sunlit Australian zoo enclosure, their similar size and joyful energy captured with soft, natural earth tones and subtle brushstrokes that emphasize their unique bond as unlikely step-siblings.

articles.title: How China’s bold talent recruitment has shaped science
articles.summary: Nature, Published online: 29 July 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02336-wMany Chinese researchers have received enviable benefits and positions after returning from training abroad.
articles.content:
Credit: Li Ziheng/Xinhua/Alamy

Materials chemist Nan Liu took a career shortcut that many researchers can only dream of. She went from a postdoctoral position in the United States to a full professor at a Chinese university with a research budget of 4 million yuan (US$560,000). Liu, now at Beijing Normal University, was recruited as part of the Thousand Young Talents Plan, a government-run initiative to bring talented overseas researchers back to China.

Over the past three decades, thousands of Chinese researchers who studied or worked abroad have returned to the country through similar talent-recruitment programmes. These recruits — who often receive substantial funding and benefits — have largely had a positive influence on China’s research landscape and contributed to its global competitiveness, say scientists.

Studies have shown that returnees have helped improve research quality, quantity and impact in China, says Lili Yang, who studies higher education at the University of Hong Kong. Many hold key positions in universities or government agencies.

But the funding and other advantages afforded to those recruited through talent programmes have caused some resentment among young Chinese researchers who remain in the country, says Jiang Li, who studies the science of science at Nanjing University in China. “They complain a lot.”

As China’s global science standing has risen, and geopolitical tensions with the United States have intensified, recruitment programmes are increasingly eyeing researchers who studied in China.

Funding and autonomy

Since the late 1990s, China has had several national-level talent recruitment programmes to attract overseas researchers, on top of hundreds of regional and local schemes. Among the largest and most prominent was the Thousand Talents Plan targeting leading researchers and entrepreneurs, which included a ‘youth’ branch for those under 40.

A rough estimate suggests that by 2018, 16,000 scientists and high-tech entrepreneurs had been recruited through various programmes to return to China.

Researchers apply for these programmes after securing a job offer at a Chinese research institute. They typically receive a sign-up bonus of at least half a million yuan, and can access several million yuan in research funding from the government and their host institute. They are also given housing subsidies and preferential treatment when applying for grants.

Around the mid-2010s, participants in the Thousand Talents Plan became a target of US government agencies, who viewed it as a channel for stealing intellectual property and trade secrets, although confirmed cases were rare. The Chinese government has since renamed the programme to the High-End Foreign Talents Plan.

More papers

Researchers have tried to study the impact of China’s talent programmes. A 2023 analysis showed that returnees who joined the youth talent programme between 2012 and 2014 published more papers than did their counterparts who stayed abroad1.

But the picture is more nuanced, say researchers. Broader studies of the scientific output of returnees, who can act as a proxy for the impact of those who returned through talent programmes, have found that they had a higher chance of being corresponding authors than did those who stayed abroad, but were less likely to publish in top-tier journals2. This, and other studies of talent recruits, suggest that returnees might not represent the highest level of international talent and are probably early in their careers, says Li, who was a co-author of the study.

A 2020 study showed that returnees authored papers that were more highly cited than those produced by their local counterparts and maintained strong publishing ties with their international colleagues3. They have “helped to raise China’s profile”, says co-author Caroline Wagner, a science-policy specialist at the Ohio State University in Columbus.

But a more recent analysis of roughly 300 Chinese returnees found that their average citations per publication declined over the five years after their return4. Their number of international collaborators and international citations also dropped over time, which point to the limits of what talent-recruitment policies can achieve, suggest the authors.
articles.reasoning: The article highlights China's successful talent recruitment efforts that have benefited many researchers returning from abroad, which suggests positive progress in scientific development and international collaboration. This can inspire hope for advancements in science and education.
articles.personality_title: China's bold talent recruitment fuels scientific progress
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
For many years, China has been working hard to bring talented scientists back from overseas to boost its research and innovation.

**What happened**
China’s Thousand Young Talents Plan has helped many researchers, like Nan Liu, return home with great support. Liu moved from a postdoc role in the U.S. to becoming a full professor in Beijing with a big research budget. This plan offers benefits like strong funding and top positions to attract skilled researchers.

**Impact**
Thanks to this effort, China has seen a rise in scientific discoveries and stronger ties with international researchers. The program helps build a thriving science community and encourages innovation.

**What's next step**
China plans to keep expanding these recruitment programs and support returning scientists, hoping to create even more opportunities for groundbreaking research.

**One-sentence takeaway**
China’s smart talent recruitment is helping build a brighter future for science by welcoming home skilled researchers with great support.
articles.personality_title_fr: Le recrutement audacieux des talents en Chine stimule le progrès scientifique
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**
Depuis plusieurs années, la Chine s'efforce de faire revenir des scientifiques talentueux de l'étranger pour renforcer sa recherche et son innovation.

**Ce qui s'est passé**
Le plan des Mille Jeunes Talents a aidé de nombreux chercheurs, comme Nan Liu, à revenir avec un fort soutien. Liu est passée d'un poste de postdoctorante aux États-Unis à professeure titulaire à Pékin avec un important budget de recherche. Ce plan offre des avantages comme un financement solide et des postes prestigieux pour attirer les chercheurs qualifiés.

**Impact**
Grâce à cet effort, la Chine a vu une augmentation des découvertes scientifiques et des liens renforcés avec des chercheurs internationaux. Le programme contribue à bâtir une communauté scientifique dynamique et encourage l'innovation.

**Prochaine étape**
La Chine prévoit de continuer à développer ces programmes de recrutement et à soutenir les scientifiques de retour, espérant créer encore plus d'opportunités pour des recherches révolutionnaires.

**En une phrase**
Le recrutement intelligent des talents en Chine aide à construire un avenir meilleur pour la science en accueillant les chercheurs qualifiés avec un grand soutien.
articles.personality_title_es: El audaz reclutamiento de talentos en China impulsa el progreso científico
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**
Durante muchos años, China ha trabajado para atraer a científicos talentosos de regreso desde el extranjero para fortalecer su investigación e innovación.

**Qué pasó**
El Plan de Mil Jóvenes Talentos ha ayudado a muchos investigadores, como Nan Liu, a regresar con un gran apoyo. Liu pasó de un puesto postdoctoral en Estados Unidos a profesora titular en Pekín con un amplio presupuesto para investigación. Este plan ofrece beneficios como financiamiento fuerte y puestos destacados para atraer a investigadores capacitados.

**Impacto**
Gracias a este esfuerzo, China ha visto un aumento en los descubrimientos científicos y vínculos más fuertes con investigadores internacionales. El programa ayuda a crear una comunidad científica próspera y fomenta la innovación.

**Próximo paso**
China planea seguir ampliando estos programas de reclutamiento y apoyando a los científicos que regresan, con la esperanza de crear aún más oportunidades para investigaciones innovadoras.

**Conclusión en una frase**
El reclutamiento inteligente de talentos en China está ayudando a construir un futuro más brillante para la ciencia al recibir a investigadores capacitados con gran apoyo.
articles.image_prompt: A detailed, warm painting of a glowing bridge made of interconnected glowing molecules and chemistry lab glassware, arching from a stylized silhouette of the United States to a vibrant skyline symbolizing a Chinese university campus, with streams of light representing research funding flowing beneath, surrounded by abstract symbols of scientific papers and collaboration networks in soft, natural hues.
